Package com.rb.nonbiz.collections

Class Partition<K>

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.collections.Partition<K>
public class Partition<K>
extends java.lang.Object
Use this whenever you want to represent having N items with proportions that sum to 1, where the items all have a positive weight.

An asset allocation that does not allow short positions is a good example.

See Also:
LinearCombination, FlatLinearCombination

  • Method Details

    • partition

      public static <K> Partition<K> partition​(RBMap<K,​UnitFraction> fractions)
      Creates a Partition from an RBMap of UnitFractions.

    • partitionFromPositiveWeightsWhichMayNotSumTo1

      public static <K,​ V extends PreciseValue<V>> Partition<K> partitionFromPositiveWeightsWhichMayNotSumTo1​(RBMap<K,​V> weightsMap)
      Creates a partition by normalizing a map of positive weights which may not sum to 100%.

      There is a similar overload that takes in DoubleMap, where the concept of summing to 100% makes more sense. Here, since we're dealing with PreciseValue, it's a bit meaningless to care about 1 vs. not 1 if the weights are of type e.g. Money. But for certain other types (UnitFraction, SignedFraction, etc.) it does make sense. However, here's no way to distinguish that given how generics work in Java. So this is reasonable.

    • partitionFromPositiveWeightsWhichMaySumToBelow1

      public static <K,​ V extends PreciseValue<V>> Partition<K> partitionFromPositiveWeightsWhichMaySumToBelow1​(RBMap<K,​V> weightsMap, Epsilon epsilon)
      Creates a partition by normalizing a map of positive weights which may sum to below 100%.

      There is a similar overload that takes in DoubleMap, where the concept of summing to 100% makes more sense. Here, since we're dealing with PreciseValue, it's a bit meaningless to care about 1 vs. not 1 if the weights are of type e.g. Money. But for certain other types (UnitFraction, SignedFraction, etc.) it does make sense. However, here's no way to distinguish that given how generics work in Java. So this is reasonable.
